comments.text:
+James Van Rude You might enjoy "People of the Lie" by M. Scott Peck, if 
you have not already read it. Been some time since I read it but one thing 
I remember him saying is the most evil people can be found in churches 
because they can more easily hide, from themselves and others, in such 
places.
comments.author: Brandi Jasmine

comments.text: +Brandi Jasmine power to you
comments.author: Gord Birch

comments.text:
+Gord Birch I had to do something similar. Not as extreme, but I was raised 
in a very fundamentalist family. I basically walked away from everyone, 
everything I knew. There is nothing in my life that was as hard as that. 
But once you see the light you cannot un-see it. I have some connections, 
still talk with my mother and a couple uncles, but there was a period of 
more than 20 years when aside from my mother I had no contact with family 
at all. And almost none with any kind of church. You can't overstate how 
difficult this must have been for them.
comments.author: Brandi Jasmine

comments.text:
+Brandi Jasmine what a hard thing for them to do, as they said to realize 
it is the last time they will see their family - but, to have peace in 
their lives they have to leave, wow, sad
comments.author: Gord Birch

comments.text:

top_comment.author: Kenneth King

comments.text:
Able Reason, thank you I appreciate your kindness. I agree interpretation 
is different for everyone, I just choose to believe that as a follower of 
Christ I cannot hate nor can I judge. I would rather put my efforts in 
helping others not condemning them. Blessings to you.
comments.author: Kenneth King

comments.text:
+Kenneth King Hi Kenneth,  I usually don't join in on the comments for 
religious discussions. I enjoy having face to face discussions with people 
about this kind of thing, but when it's done in writing it usually becomes 
a time consuming and ultimately useless exercise. However, I did want to 
make the effort to contact you to say that although I disagree with you on 
religious matters I can still admire your approach to communicating.  You 
don't change your tone to match the negativity of someone who gets overly 
emotional or attacks you or your beliefs and I think that is all too rare. 
I am not in some position of superiority that enables me to say 'Well done' 
to you, but I would like to offer a 'Well done' anyway, within the spirit 
of friendliness and appreciation.  You seem to be trying to embody the 
positive aspects of your religious text and I find that admirable. 
At the same time, I must say that there are many who are not doing what you 
do, and that is, from my perspective, the problem with religious texts.
+Aumish is correct in saying that the actions of WBC are justified within 
one interpretation of the bible. Southern American slave owners defended 
the morality of the institution of slavery based on actual biblical text as 
well. Ever since the Reformation anyone is free to interpret scripture as 
they see fit, as well as to pick and choose what parts to pay attention to 
and what parts to ignore. You only have to look at the thousands of 
different Christian denominations to see that there is no accepted 
authority on the 'correct' interpretation of the Bible. It seems to me, as 
I believe one of them said in the video, that sacred texts like the Torah, 
the Bible, the Quran etc. can be, and are, used to justify what a person or 
group Already Believes, good or bad, and then those beliefs become 
unassailable because they are 'The Sacred Word Of God', allowing religious 
belief to be a source of great sorrow and grief at the same time as being a 
source of love and life.
Anyway, regardless of whether you respond or not, or what your response 
might be, let me finnish up in the same spirit as I began, by saying Stay 
Positive. Humanity needs all the positivity it can get. I wish you and the 
ones you love a good, healthy and fulfilling life.
comments.author: Able Reason

comments.text:

top_comment.text:
I find it very interesting when people who don't read the bible or obey the 
Word of God, want to talk about the message of the bible and what it says. 
While I do agree that WBC lacks compassion and their message is out of 
balance because they don't tell people how to be reconciled with God etc... 
God is not tolerant of sin and he does not embrace it either. We all have 
sinned and fallen short of the glory of God. That is how we were separated 
from God, it is through our sin! That is why Jesus came to earth to die on 
the cross and by doing so he took the penalty for our sins upon himself. 
The penalty for sin is Death both physical and spiritual, so that through 
faith in him and Repentance we could be reconciled with God, be forgiven 
and become his children. But we Must repent our sins and be born again of 
the water and of the Spirit in order to enter the kingdom of God. Stop 
trying to vilify the bible as hateful because it doesn't agree with your 
flawed morality and sinful lifestyle. Sin is hateful, when we sin against 
our neighbors we are hating them.﻿

comments.text:
I think there is some kind of attention seeking going on. Here we are, 
posting and arguing about them. Everyone I know knows who they are. All 
kinds of various feelings about them and their actions.
Yet the reality, and why I try and ignore them. Is that it's seriously 3 
people in a Car driving from Kansas. The closer to their base 
of operations and it's logistical distance... re: have to get a hotel, have 
to stay overnight. "how many people and what kind of gas millage will we 
get".
have a direct relationship to the size of the 'protest'.... 

Most protests having nothing to do with the issue, but that it's within 
driving distance of Kansas without an overnight stay.... and you get enough 
'protesters' to fill one car and 6 signs. because that fills the car. one 
seat and a trunk = 6 signs, and 3 people holding 6 signs is like 6 people.
When you see the 'protest' photo it's usually 2-3 people each holding 2 
signs.
You only get 2 protesters if they have to stay overnight, because they need 
baggage.

comments.text:
+notavalidpoint

points. And I suppose I could concede that his boisterous style does add to 
the debate. Thanks for the discussion mate. I must admit they are 
entertaining, :)
comments.author: AndyPips

comments.text:
Well, I don't disagree. I guess I'm more tolerant of his bias because I 
often agree with his views, however heavy-handed he may be. At least there 
are other, more affable hosts to smooth over his style.
comments.author: notavalidpoint

comments.text:
Valid journalism is unbiased, I'm not impressed with his style. Saying that 
I do like the show, I don't think he's doing himself any favours, thats 
all. So much journalism has got an agenda these days, they could be doing 
more good by presenting raw facts for the audience to digest for themselves.
comments.author: AndyPips

comments.text:

news cast. TYT always fill most of their time with opinions. Although Cenk 
is a bit of a mic hog.

comments.text: It is indeed, but I'm not doing a job that requires me to be unbiased.
